I did my 4 year bachelor at BuAs and at that time it felt right for me :) I find it hard to say how that should change now though. I think if an animation student who had done the same program as me those years ago, they might still have the same chances.

responses.year_1_focus: Foundational Art Skills (traditional principles)
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Adapting to new technology is a must but always keep in mind that you are the artist/creator. The deep essence of any role in the entertainment industry is the capability to be creative and have a voice. Disregard that and you are just a tool.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: Foundational skills will always be more important as the human brain works with a feeling foremost. AI is something that cannot convey a feeling. So in my opinion it always comes down to foundational skills
responses.graduate_skills_gap: understanding what it means to be an artist/creative.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: any new technology needs to be looked at educationally, not in the sense it will replace workflows.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Be open enough to allow creativity in the mundane singular pursuit of high success while also strive to support human ideas first rather than technology.

responses.graduate_skills_gap: What's most common for people I work with, is working within a modular system; getting graduates familiar with modular systems and design, will be helpful when working on commercial projects.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: I'd personally go with procedural generation; think PCG in Unreal. It doesn't need to be a complex full course, but it's already helpful for students to understand the core concepts of it.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.

responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: working with your team, knowing your role and what you can contribute, but also cross disciplinary exchange of knowledgem, ideas and opinions. A lot of problems arise when disciplines dont change perspective and know about how and what other disciplines are doing and need. Communication/Understanding is key!
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Focus on software-agnostic principles.
responses.ai_role: Knowledge of AI will be crucial for any artist.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: I just graduated but I for myself, I think it is optimization even tho it is not priority for graduates to know but I know that people might be confused why this doesnt get teached more.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Blender
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Give art students more of a choice what art style and topic they want to work on. Specifically the personal projects often had topics that did not combine well with what I wanted to practice and get better at. For the majority of the study the university did not give me space to grow in what I wanted to do later. Maybe I was too niesh. Teachers support was also bare minimum or me working on what I liked to do later got surpressed. Give students the freedom if they have a plan for their future!

critical_technical_subdisciplines: Tools & Pipeline Scripting (Python for VFX; Python/C# for Games)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: 25/75 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools. Technical skills are extremely sought after
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Art should follow, reinforce, and show a deep understanding of gameplay the art is meant for. It's important for new visual art students to learn game design principles as well, not just focusing on traditional art methods or making things look pretty. We see the same mistakes in the industry over and over regarding artists ignoring or not understanding the gameplay requirements of the features they are building. There should also be a focus on learning how to build quick, usable in the game prototypes rather than only the final polished piece. These skills are equally important
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Teach specific industry standards in depth (Unreal, Nuke, Houdini).
responses.ai_role: Knowledge of AI will be crucial for any artist.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: A lack of confidence in own abilities. Or overconfidence in a lack of abilities. The results of graduation are extremely dependent on the person in question and how they conducted themselves during said education.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Mobile
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Focus on building projects in multi disciplinary teams as early as possible

responses.primary_industry: All 3, currently in game dev, but also as an educator, so a little bit of everything
future_specializations_demand: Over the next 3 - 5 years, students in the digital arts need to be proficient with understanding AI enabled workflows. My personal feeling is the digital arts are going to change dramatically over the next 2 (two) years. This applies to all disciplines. Starting in 2026, our field is going to continue to undergo dramatic change due to global AI implementation.
critical_technical_subdisciplines: Tools & Pipeline Scripting (Python for VFX; Python/C# for Games)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: Mostly focus on traditional skills, traditional skills will set students apart from less well trained competing candidates. I believe a more generalist mindset will be valued, supervisory skills, being able to produce quality art and being well trained in AI workflows.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Without a doubt in my mind: The ability to think with reasonlogic and AI literacy.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: A healthy mix of the 1st and 3rd options (foundational skills mixed with strong knowledge of how to use AI workflows)
responses.graduate_skills_gap: We are currently in a historical technological change with AI, so my gut instinct is that how our industries work currently is going to undergo startling changes.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: LLMs and generative software workflows, the fields are accelerating at a breathtaking pace.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Being highly skilled in traditional art and techniques will set students apart in the long run. We are now in a tech situation where one artist can do a LOT more and have a lot more tools and agentic tools. Being able to plan and direct for small strike team or studio approach, one well trained artist who knows how to supervise and think long range will be able to do incredible volumes of work.

responses.primary_industry: Both (e.g., Cinematics, VP, XR, Cross-Over Projects)
critical_technical_subdisciplines: Math, basic CS, history of rendering
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: Foundational Art Skills (traditional principles)
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Every student, no matter the discipline, should have a pretty clear understanding of how electricity in power socket turns into game frame displayed on the screen
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Focus on software-agnostic principles.
responses.ai_role: Ai is just a tool. Student should understand how it works, then student will be able to use it efficiently with awareness about limitations

responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Landing a dream job is not just about having the best portfolio. Having a strong portfolio is importent, but networking is equally important. I have landed my last 3 jobs all thought my network I have build up over the years, backed by my portfolio.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: I would not teach any AI. Leave that for the individual to decide.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: It seems generally technical students (tech art, animation, procedural etc) have no problem finding jobs. But the more general art focussed portfolios (env art, character art etc) often lack quality in their portfolios. They need to try to stand out more with bigger scoped unique projects.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: No specific technology stands out, but for general 3d work blender is becoming the standard. Also plasticity for any hard surface modeling and concepting. Lastly, because the tools are getting better and better, highly specialized roles are becoming more generalistic. In the future everyone can do a bit of everything, and teams are getting smaller..
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: One area that could use more focus, at least back when I was there, was hard surface design/concepting. I think a general ''concepting'' class would be a cool addition where people learn about environment, character/creature and hard surface concepting. (if this doesn't exist yet anyway)

responses.ai_role: Ai can be used for inspiration/moodboarding, but will not teach someone how to make design decisions, as AI takes that critical thinking part
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Gap between graduating and getting into the industry? Not specializing enough. You can tell when a portfolio is a studentportfolio without focus, very much all over the place, jack of all trades master of none. Which often means that the graduate does not meet the standard that is required for specific roles. I'd recommend creating focus, pick a specialization, stick to it, become really good, and after you land the job, you can branch out again. A jack of all trades has it's place, most often in indie studios, where you need to wear multiple hats. But if a graduate wants to work at bigger studios, they will look for specialization.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Not AI, big taboo

responses.ai_role: Having an understanding of AI and learn about how it can be a tool for production usage
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Focus Dependent, but what I have seen for many students who went down the 4 yr university program to learn Animation is That animation took a back seat to a more generalist approach. students who thought they would get more Animation fundamentals training really took a back seat to the other production disciplines. Thus, becoming disappointed and discouraged in the end. Ultimately, they extended their education with a more focused Animation training at Animation centric on line schools such as AMentor, IAnimate, Animschool and the like.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: I certainly think touching on AI as it starts to find it's way into production. It will be interesting to see how this All plays out once the Frenzied Dust settles. being proficient in the Unreal engine world is a plus for sure.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Don't throw everything at the Student(s) all at once. Introduce and Build on their understanding both artistically and Technically for whatever path they want to focus on. They have to be able to digest things realistically as the new technology emerges.

responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Make it realistic. With a lot of universities there is a problem that they claim you will get a job after finishing your studies, while in many cases students are not properly prepared. Make sure they know it can be tough and they need to put their own effort apart from just studying to get the results.

I would select Proc Gen Houdini, but AI tooling for pipelines is already taking over, you can implement LMs directly in Houdini and in engines like Unreal and Unity, look at tools like Bezi which feed the entire project to an AI model. This is already here, it has already taken hold at the biggest companies and there are billions being invested in enterprise level generative AI tools.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: To me from my perspective, working in this industry you have to be passionate great driven solo player, who also wants to thrive within a team. because you need all your coworkers for the final product to become a succes. and when you work with other disciplines simultaniously , you need to be an actual team and understand other people and what they do as well, be passionate, stay motivated and want to help your peers will get you really far. its your communication skills and how you add your value towards a team. the hard and soft skills can be learned through education and time and labor. but finding that right work ethic needs to be practised.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: Depending on the AI tools that you are using, For instance i use chatgpt on the daily, if its for finding issues, writing scripts for maya. generating images though shouldnt be a main focus i think but a nice exploration for students to play with since it does safe a lot of time when tools are used well. but shouldnt be replaced by foundational skills ofcourse.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Portfolio wise, when you look at people who have graduated from Buas , you see that they went through the pipeline, experimented, got the fundamentals teached and are specialising in a certain role. people who are hobbyist or self though tend to have a more diverse portfolio from what I've seen , which is less focused. and dont show fundamentals most of the time ( if im generalizing the majority )
responses.emerging_technology_integration: generative AI , theres even AI already that is creating 3d models -> pipeline is still not nice though because it needs optimization. otherwise im unsure, I havent seen stuff that is ''insanely'' new and or used as of now.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: when i was on Buas, i had group projects from y2 block A till the end of my y3. I would give the possibility for people to keep doing this, but also for people to explore more within year 2. more lectures, or groups you could join to practice. I also feel like lots of students are trying to only push perfectly polished things to artstation ( myself included when i studied ). Studies are also always just nice to see if presented right, a speedsculpt for example as character artist, with just polypainted that is rendered right also does the job to showcase your skills. ( less documentation would be nice, and more time on getting those soft/hard skills ) all in all I think buas is doing great, maybe post more on linkedin, showcase work from students or tell students to be more active on linkedin after each project, and that they shouldnt be afraid to contact people. ive had some students approach me and ask for feedback and i think most of my coworkers would love to give feedback to people. encourage them to be brave and just go for it!

responses.year_1_focus: Foundational Art Skills (traditional principles)
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: The one thing that can't be skipped is having a good eye. Students need to develop visual taste and the artistic judgment to create assets that look intentional and high-quality in any style.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: Knowledge of AI will be crucial for any artist.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: The biggest gap I see in graduates from 4-year programs is the lack of variety and volume in their portfolios. Most students focus on one or two big, polished projects, but in a real work environment, you rarely have the time or resources to create a 'masterpiece.' I’d love to see more small-scale projects like quick sculpts, concept models, and visual studies. These kinds of projects give a much better picture of how someone works on a daily basis and how they think as an artist.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: AI tools in general
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Give students more, smaller projects instead of just a few big ones. Big projects are great, but doing only one or two over several months doesn’t give students enough variety or practice. Shorter, focused projects help them learn faster, try different styles and workflows, and get used to working within time constraints. This is much closer to how things work in a studio. It also leads to stronger, more well-rounded portfolios.

responses.emerging_technology_integration: Using AI but as a tool, for ex., I've seen how concept artists can use it: drawing the front orthographic projection of a building or a prop and using AI to make it isometric 3d view is super fast and useful. So using AI as a time saving tool is great, but not for art generation please, the result is too generic - unless generic is what you need
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: More focus on the core skills and portfolio and less pipelines (at least for character, real-time vfx, environment, animation art). Each company has its own pipelines anyway. Mb less group projects - often useless for portfolio and less time on the core skills. So knowing industry standard software + really great core skills should be enough

responses.graduate_skills_gap: Often I see student portfolios being let down by arbitrary performance constraints and a lack of understanding on acceptable triangle counts, a simple example is that there is almost no need anymore to see polygonal cylinders, but we still see them everywhere, when asked about it the usual response is it had to be low-poly

responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Prepare students for a broad range of companies, AAA is usually what is wanted but spots are limited and falling between the cracks is worse than working for a company that might not be your dream company straight away.

critical_technical_subdisciplines: Tools & Pipeline Scripting (Python for VFX; Python/C# for Games)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: I’d love for art fundamentals to be applied in the way we will use them. Instead of traditional drawing how would you apply composition in a 3D level? How does light and shadow work in engine? Sure life drawing is nice, but it is hard for a student to grasp how to apply that to the education they signed up for, which is art for games. I feel like the study is for GAME art, not just art. Otherwise the students could just go to an art school.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: I think this goes for both students and teachers. It is a game art course and thus the teachers need to be up to date on that industry and not just ‘art’. Painting and core art principles are great, but it isn’t utilized in a good way for this course if it is not applied in a logical way that makes students understand that it is being made for a digital medium. Also game art is a team sport, diversity in people AND skills is encouraged, there is no place for a talented bully. When I entered the industry I liked to work according to; I don’t know how to do that YET, but I will try. This applies to everything a project need, not just the very limited things I enjoy doing.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: They go hand in hand. Core principles can be carried with you to any software. If you know Maya then you know Blender in a weekend. Engines should be taught according to what is needed. Depending on game complexity, is this a prototype or not, platform, etc. It might be smarter to swap to a different engine.
responses.ai_role: AI is another temporary buzzword, core art skills will win out every time and will age gracefully no matter what.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: communication with other disciplines. The giant lack of knowledge about others in your team makes for poor communication. You need to have a base understanding of every team members role and how they get applied. This makes for a smoother work process and better project results overall.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Not AI, as that’s what everyone has been focusing on. Improve the core art fundamentals that are getting taught and stand out like that.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Please start applying art principles in digital ways within engines. Making art is 1 thing, making it work in engine is another which should be the focus of this game art course. This will immediately also make sure that the students know how to use things like Perforce and project planning tools from the beginning.

critical_technical_subdisciplines: Tools & Pipeline Scripting (Python for VFX; Python/C# for Games)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Other people are going to work on your stuff and your stuff is going to be worked on by others. If you work for someone else, none of the work you make is yours. If you don't like this, go the independent route.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Focus on software-agnostic principles.
responses.ai_role: Knowledge of AI will be crucial, but therefore fundamental skills become more important. AI can be a valuable tool.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: They need to learn how to negotiate and push for better pay earlier. Because you're going to get shafted - it's tough out here. And by accepting low pay you're collectively bringing down the value of the labour.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Using LLMs to help with scripting but always challenge the output.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Stick with the fundamentals. Don't worry about forever evolving tech or software. But still show them a bit of everything in the first year.

critical_technical_subdisciplines: Tools & Pipeline Scripting (Python for VFX; Python/C# for Games)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: A Specialist: Highly proficient in one discipline.
responses.year_1_focus: Foundational Art Skills (traditional principles)
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: For artists; artistic fundamentals (Colour, Light, Shape Language mostly) are fundamental to every single discipline within Art, and there are little roles (save the extremely technical ones) that are not directly affected by your skill level in them
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: AI will most likely be a tool that cuts out the mundane work. all the more important to have extremely good fundamental artistic skills if you want to enter the industry.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: The soft-skills built working with teams from multiple disciplines. Hard skills are somewhat comparable to other programmes, but being able to manage to collaborate with other people is such an amazing skill; I noticed it a lot during applications as well (being from BUAS was a definite +)
responses.emerging_technology_integration: In my opinion: Acrylic paints and a brush. Tech changes wildly and very quickly, but the one constant between every highly skilled and achieving artist is great artistic fundamentals. Making them less optional as Visual Literacy exercises would help students grow I think.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Ditch AI. I understand that it can be useful in the industry (I encouter it plenty); but as a STUDENT it should NOT be touched. The only purpose of AI is to skip steps because you are experienced and have done it 100 times before, but studetns havent. So have them draw it out in 3D perspective, or recolour a piece to different lighting. The tools are great, but there is no skill involved in using them, whereas there is more than enough to learn in regards to true artistic skills.

responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: You need to use references to make good art, even if that art isn't realistic.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: Foundational skills will become more important.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Graduates often seem so confused. 3D modelling is taught in a very convoluted way, instead of learning one way through the pipeline you end up learning both too much in some areas, and too little in others. As a result, students are lacking in other areas like their technical skill (they don't make the right decisions because they don't understand why they do something a certain way) or they're behind on foundational artistic skills (thanks to them not finishing enough projects, because projects become too confusing and difficult to complete).
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Unsure, I mainly work on mobile games, where polygon limits are no longer that important but art and 3d fundamentals are, so I would always recommend teaching foundational knowledge over new tech.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: If you guide students in doing what they loLimiting students to realism or stylised art ultimately really does not matter. You can still learn anatomy from stylised art, and you can apply flow to realism (taught through fashion design, for example). There is no need to encourage students to do one or the other, as long as they make proper use of reference and are learning to understand key concepts. Character art is often overcomplicated, teach students one way through the pipeline first, but make it clear it isn't the only way. Then introduce more complex ways of doing things as appropriate. Explain why UV padding and directional UVs are important, teach retopology in a simple way (articulation loops first, then build on that knowledge) and let students paint normal maps. I also don't think project lab is all that useful for character artists. I understand that everybody else benefits from them being a part of it, but character artists really just need to sit down and lock in. Communication skills are important, but you're expected to learn those as you work anyway.

responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: When you're working on a multidisciplinary project, understand that you're all on the same team trying to work towards the same goal - creating something that you can show off & be proud of for many years to come, together. Learning how to collaborate with others is absolutely crucial to succeed in the industry.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Both are important - a good way to approach this is to teach them side by side: explain core principles, directly followed by a practical application of them in one of said tools.
responses.ai_role: Difficult to say - it's a tool that is used by some disciplines more than others, but still requires human input for finetuning in the end (with the current state of things).
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Some people focus too much on developing a personal portfolio with unique benchmarks instead of focusing on collaboration with a team. When applying for a job, being able to showcase communication & collaboration skills will get you a lot further than just a bunch of pretty renders.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: ML technologies are widely used across the board in many companies. Scripting & coding with the help of AI is common, though it's important to understand the core principles before doing this to understand why things inevitably fail.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Encourage communication between disciplines, both on the student and lecturer level. If lecturers aren't able to collaborate with each other across disciplines, it won't encourage students to do so either, giving them all a handicap once they enter the industry. You can achieve so much more working as a collective unit rather than a big group of individuals with their own unique agendas.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: Foundational Art Skills (traditional principles)
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Art fundamentals: Flow, shape language and composition.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: Foundational skills will become more important.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Portfolio skills. 1. Strategically deciding which skills you want to 'prove' or represent with your next portfolio piece. (I often see students creating very similar pieces multiple times) 2. Portfolio presentation is often lacking in graduates' work, and is often dragging down an otherwise decent piece. Lack of understanding of 3-point lighting or Unreal/Marmoset lighting principles, not using value groups and color theory to enhance the qualities of their 3D work. It's all fundamental skills that student 3D artists often ignore.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: I would not teach visual generative AI. The companies I've worked at will reject any portfolio that has signs of generative AI. However DO teach students how to write automization scripts using AI for their 3D software.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: I believe the curriculum around 2018 was not focusing enough on personal portfolio work, leaving many students with a watered down portfolio, mostly group projects. I think many technical skills can be taught on the job/internship - except raw art fundamentals. So my advice would be to split the curriculum into 50% personal, 50% group projects, and prepare students with 2-3 strong personal portfolio pieces that are designed to highlight specific skills and getting their foot into the industry.

responses.primary_industry: Both (e.g., Cinematics, VP, XR, Cross-Over Projects)
future_specializations_demand: (Tech) Artists with the flexibility to work on technical problems and/or work with difficult/unfinished tools.
critical_technical_subdisciplines: Leveraging standard skills to obtain new skills in a pragmatic way (i.e. not learning python, but learning how to leverage certain parts of python to solve your speficic problem). Also how to leverage AI tools in order to produce code, models, textures, etc faster than someone who is not using AI tools.
responses.graduate_profile_preference: A Generalist: Competent across multiple disciplines.
responses.year_1_focus: The foundations of modelling, texturing are the foundations of understanding procedural tools, which in turn are the foundation to learn to do things ever more efficient or to become a versatile problem solver who can work and think outside the box.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Understanding each other's work and it's effects on the general project. An artist or engineer should no longer be stuck inside the boundaries of their own work. An artist should have a high level understanding of how code works, without needing to know the syntax. An engineer should know how shaders, animations and meshes work without the need to know modelling. In our company many engineers have a solid understanding of art related subjects, which makes them see opportunities to apply their core skills to different subjects.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Industry standard with the addition that concepts from Houdini, Unreal and Nuke carry over in many inhouse or custom tools.That knowledge is invaluable! (For instance understanding blending of layers in photoshop is similar to blending in shaders)
responses.ai_role: AI is replacing the need to master a code syntax or to learn specific 3d tool workflows: but it does require you to still understand the core concepts of the 'trade'. For example, Cursor can write python scripts or shaders for you, but you still need to be able to know what to ask of it. So it's more about core concepts, foundational skills and applying those to current AI based tools in order to get quick and efficient results.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: The old school trade of making animations, models and code versus the ways AI tools can now generate complete animation sets, fully optimized assets or code within minutes.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Absolutely AI - Like I wrote, asking perplexity to explain problems to you, asking Cursor to write you code or code blocks makes it really easy to run through issues without having to spend hours reading documentation.Cursor can write a shader and you can ask it to explain the code it written, basically being your 'servant' and teacher at the same time. You can be super productive and realize your ideas without having to spend months learning a language or tool.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: It's great if students could be show the broader application than just within game projects. responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Scoping, starting, and finishing collaborative projects. I credit the game development club I participated in for a majority of the skills I learned that I needed to begin my career, so learning skills in classes while applying them directly to completing passion projects is a key concept in my opinion.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Focus on software-agnostic principles.
responses.ai_role: No skills with AI needed. If the role of AI stays steady, artists will not need to know how to use the services at all since, like at my studio, the art will be generated without need of hiring an artist to do it. (This is specifically 2d character illustrations since we don't have any illustrators on staff, which I personally object to.) That said, I forsee specialized (and hopefully deterministic 🙄) generative models being incorporated into procedural node based DCCs.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: This may be down to the individual, but I've seen and heard graduates only having one semester experience with a DCC and only in class projects to show for a portfolio.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Emerging technologies that excite me and I see being integrated more into our creative industries are the free and open source ones. I think it would be a boon to students to learn off of free software tools like Godot, Blender, and Material Maker, and teach how to transfer those skills to proprietary software like Unreal and Maya. I just learned of this yesterday so maybe really bleeding edge is a procedural 2D tool called Graphite (https://graphite.rs/). Also, the JangaFX suite of tools are very cool and useful.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: I encourage your program to teach foundational and transferable skills then facilitate creative collaboration between students. My entire portfolio upon graduating was student made games I worked on in between classes. I believe course assignments are vital to testing the basics, but to really develop skill, students need to apply what they learn to what they're passionate about, which won't always happen in class.

critical_technical_subdisciplines: The latest VFX and Lighting pipelines in-engine. The technical side of creating environments that a regular environment artist won't be able to do. (Niagara VFX, Houdini VFX integration into unreal/unity, Optimization, all latest render pipelines in Unreal)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Teamwork. The majority of the time you will be working in teams in the industry. You need to learn how to work together with people from very different backgrounds and perspectives in life. Most job opportunities will come from people you know (especially the friends that you have now in your class). People will recommend you based on how nice you are to work with. During interviews the people that are excited and pleasant to communicate with will get picked over people that have better skills but are disagreeable or have poor communication skills.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: AI will not replace artists, but will make the demand for certain roles less. (Concept art is highly competitive already, even more with AI, but VFX is still high in demand because AI can not replace it). There will always be a demand for artists that are heavily specialized. But there will be less demand for mediocre 2D art and 3D art if AI can replace it. Bigger studios will often not use AI to avoid damaging the brand, but smaller studios will likely use it more to safe costs.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Outdated software knowledge. Students need to learn industry standard software and pipelines. You kinda want the students to be 1 year ahead of the industry instead of 5 years behind. When there are job listings, companies are often hiring people that know more about software than themselves. For example, if Unreal introduces a new lighting pipeline, people at the company don't have time to learn it, so they want to hire someone who already knows how it works. Texturing same thing. Nobody paints textures in Photoshop anymore, everything is done in Substance Painter and Substance Designer.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Blender, Marmoset (Zbrush, Substance Painter, Substance Designer are already a must-have)
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Be hyper aware and stay up to date with industry-standard software and pipelines. It is rapidly evolving. The industry is still warming up to Blender, but the way it is going right now Blender might de-throne Maya in the future. Maya is still industry standard, so that knowledge is still required.

responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Have teachers act as lead for a group project. Students don't know what they are doing and they can learn best by example. It is inspiring to see how your lead handles issues and how they build trust with their teams.

responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Teach specific industry standards in depth (Unreal, Nuke, Houdini).

responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Focus on optimization too, games suffer from bad behaviour and games just needing to look pretty. Make games with a certain budget in frametime, learn about ISM, drawcalls, batching, raster bins, lightmaps as alternative, or maybe a hybrid distance based lighting solution, tools to optimize, PIX, Insights, etc.

responses.ai_role: Any self respecting university should not be teaching their students to plagiarize, plus it removes the learning from the course for the students especially at the start, and generative AI is at best a random number generator that uses probability to determine its next token entire trained on actual people's work and will have major faults and biases in what information it relays. As for art, you cannot have your students use other people's art as their own, as that is once again plagiarism and will harm their future in the industry as companies cannot use AI and own creative license at the same time.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: A lack of scripting skills and soft skills.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Anti-AI protection for creative property.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Prevent use of AI in project work as this is actively hurting the learning and knowledge capabilities of your students; studies have already shown that active use of AI is damaging to our critical thinking skills: https://www.mdpi.com/2075-4698/15/1/6

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: Foundational Art Skills (traditional principles)
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Art Fundamentals and Critical Creative Thinking. This is something AI can't easily replace.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: Foundational Skills will become more important, but knowledge of AI will be crucial for any artist. You need to have the right foundational and creative skills to solve what AI can't, however AI as a tool in the process can't be ignored either.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: I don't know enough about recent graduates to answer this.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: AI is already in the process of turning our industry upside down, but it can't do everything and I think it is very important to highlight this and deeply consider how various tools like this affect our ever evolving fast changing industry.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: A focus on very creative output (concept artist can still thrive for example as AI struggles to be truly innovative, we may see an increase of art directors even) and very technically complex processes (Just being a 3D modeller probably won't cut it with 3D generation already being used in workforce as a starting point for asset creation, it'll probably still be a job, but less of it with a higher focus on I think more technically advanced roles) as well as things AI is generally bad at is probably most important to consider. The art foundations are still king here and must be understood and practiced as without those any of these roles will fall apart, so always emphasizing the focus on fundamentals throughout the 4 years will be crucial for development in my opinion

responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Always work from coarse to fine. Make big changes while working in big coarse low detail steps while big changes are cheap. Only make small adjustments and tweaks and polish in the end-phase when working on fine details.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Teach core underlying principles. Teach students how to learn new software quickly, tools change all the time, they will have to learn new tools during their career many times.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: This is a tough one. AI will become much more important. In an ideal world AI solves the right problems and takes away the boring chores and laborious mind-numbing work, letting skilled and creative people focus on the fun creative part of the job more effectively. More realistically, certain companies will try to replace people with generative AI, and it will be difficult for other companies who do not want that to stay competitive.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: It differs per student, but from my experience only the top-students are offered a job after their internship. The middle chunk of the bell curve often lacks the skill levels or effectiveness / productivity and creativity that we are looking for.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Unreal's PCG system. And learning how to use AI tools to speed up the production process while still maintaining human creativity.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: One key characteristic we are looking for in our employees is a high degree of problem solving skills, finding creative ways to succeed and excel, using knowledge from more senior team members to quickly grow in their role.

Bend to the rules and being adaptable is a core perk in game dev, stay flexible, drop the ego. (This only applies to someone who gets started)
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Teach specific industry standards in depth (Unreal, Nuke, Houdini).
responses.ai_role: Foundational skills will become more important.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: How to properly treat UVs, this wasn't taught to me during my curriculum and I learned it through my internship and it could have been covered by the program.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Unreal Engine, its not new but its evolving every year and the students will be valuable assets to any company if they understand it.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: I am a graduate from 2022, I think that the system was already pretty strong, I like the amount of group project throughout the years. If one thing could be improved, I would push for more workshop from people within the industry, ask the students what they are missing and finding people that can teach them the missing knowledge. Not everything can be found on the internet and I find that paying a school should come with some basics.

responses.primary_industry: Both (e.g., Cinematics, VP, XR, Cross-Over Projects)
responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: optimization! efficiency! don't rely on fancy new features like Lumen and Nanite!!!
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: Focus on software-agnostic principles.
responses.ai_role: Foundational skills will become more important.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: knowing how to develop efficiently, in an optimized manner. Almost all projects have terrible performance with the graduates unaware and ignorant on how to address it. Also too many students focus on creation of stylized-only assets. Learn how to create real objects, people, environments before you break the rules for fantasy creation.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: 3D Laser scanning, Photogrammetry, 3D Guassian Splatting, and the entire content pipeline from those to optimized assets.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Artists have to understand how engines work, so that their work is actually usable and they know what is possible. Too many rely on performance heavy engine features to do the work for them. Learn the difference between deferred and forward rendering in unreal, and learn to develop performant projects for mobile FIRST before developing for PC or anything else. Art fundamentals without technical competence to make things work for non-highend platforms is useless more often than not.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Node graphs. Whether it's geonodes, houdini, bueprint, pcg, unreal materials, designer, comfyui, liquigen - having a solid foundational understanding of how to manipulate vectors, coordinates and colors makes you better at everything.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: Similar to procedural content generation. An artist using AI in an appropriate context will be more productive. It is a not a substitute for foundational skills.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: I'd like to see non-technical artists employ some more foundational TA skills to enhance their workflows. Basic scripting for import/export pipelines, repetitive modeling tasks, etc. On the flipside, students who focus specifically on TA could present something more polished and complete in context.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: I would promote a wider toolbelt where artists integrate tools like Plasticity and SDF modeling alongside SubD and sculpting to get the best out of many worlds. AI has a place in 3D art, similar to procedural content generation. It alone cannot replace a 3D Artist, but a 3D Artist who knows how and when to use it is going to count for two.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: I think graduation project in general would benefit from being more integrated in a complete product. If it's a character, set up an animation blueprint for it. If it's a game environment, have a mannequin or vehicle move around in it. If it's a procedural tool, show how it looks when used to generate quantities of content that justify making the tool. The artist should be responsible for integration and optimization. Showing a piece of content in an isolated scene or render leaves the question for me; how much work will I have making this work in the game?.

responses.graduate_skills_gap: I have rarely had any issues with feeling like graduates lack preparation. If I had to say something, then it is to manage expectations. Read the roll you apply for and ask to clarify what your primary work will be.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: AI. It can help a lot for self-learning but students must know how to use it and where it can give bad advice.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Personally I think that students should keep an open mind and know the tools surrounding their trade. I would expect anyone applying for games to have integrated their assets into an engine, and animators to know the basics of how a rig can break.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Collaborative work is most important. Egoistical ideas could be a hinderance in projects, especially on higher roles. Its important to share work load even if its on the same model/problem. People should be able to step in to fix/review/suggest exisiting work, even if its now your own work. We're working on a game as a team effort, not a fight for the spotlight.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.scripting_teaching_approach: Focus only on Technical Art / TD students.
responses.ai_role: In some areas its a must to have AI experience, while other companies are against it. Depending on what they aim for, it should be an option to learn. But they must understand that AI should not replace their learning. Learning the fundementals are crucial in order to use AI effectively. AI should not be a replacement for their own work, it should be a tool.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Assuming this is about graduates vs employed. Mostly experience and fear of asking questions. This also depends per company, but in my case people shouldn't be afraid of asking questions and making mistakes. Learning how to act on mistakes is important, how to communicate well and document is a must.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: AI should be implemented, wether optional or mandatory, its no denying that it has already changed the industry a lot. Wether I agree with it or not. It would be good if Art understood some basics with tooling, for example Python. This will help with their development and also how to ask for new tools from TA.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Artists should learn how to adapt to new challenges. What I've noticed is that Artists hate documentation, reading and changes, even if the changes are for their benefit. It would be good if Art would be more open to learning new tools. Art can be selfish and wanting their work to be only theirs and put all of their time and effort into what matters to them, not the project. This could be a fault with the curriculum, to reward more on big individual pieces.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: Immediately start with professional group projects; learning skills will follow from that, it's something students pick up themselves anyway. This should continue during the course of the education, with increasing difficulty.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Working in a team.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: You can teach software to students, but you have to realize that they can find all that stuff on the internet. It's the application of that knowledge that you can't find on the internet: this is why you should immediately start with full fledged professional fictional projects.
responses.ai_role: lol no comment
responses.graduate_skills_gap: 3D modelers have no clue how models are used in set dressing. For instance: a modular set is worth much more than a 3D model you can only use once. 3D modelers should have a deep understanding of setdressing.
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Definitely procedural content creation. Anything that makes it cheaper and faster for studios to create lots of content. Although in my opinion a lot of manual work is still required in the foreseeable future.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: When teaching people looking to be an artist in the games industry, it's best teach them to be mindful of what studios are looking for, and be patient with personal preferences. Everyone wants to be a character artist, so you're competing with the absolute best. Unless you're a superstar with lots of experience, getting hired as a character artist for a major studio is unlikely. Assembling a good portfolio should be mindful of this. Maybe game educations should include lessons in how to assemble a good portfolio.

responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: Foundational skills will remain equally important. Knowledge of where AI can remove grunt work will be crucial for any artist.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: Students should be aware that most art positions in video games are getting more and more technical, and they should spend some of their time during their 4 years grinding technical aspects, even if that is not their main interest. It will be ever more difficult to succeed in the workplace as an artist purely based on artistic merit; it is plain easier to succeed if that merit is paired with technical proficiency so that technology doesn't limit the artist's creative expression.

responses.graduate_profile_preference: T-Shaped: Deeply specialized in one area with broad pipeline understanding.
responses.year_1_focus: A 50/50 blend of art fundamentals and digital tools.
responses.core_concept_non_negotiable: Almost every student is an incredible artist. Good art alone isn't what makes you stand out. A good understanding of WHY you made certain decisions in your portfolio work makes a better impression. Was your camera top-down isometric? If so, what did you do to the back of your models? Did you match the texture resolution to the camera distance? Old-school optimization is still incredibly relevant. Studio's don't expect a student be perfect at this, but to show you at least think about it will put you above any shiny render without any breakdowns.
responses.core_software_teaching_approach: A hybrid approach: principles first, then depth in key tools.
responses.ai_role: The further we go in this AI-future, the less worried I get about its impact on our industry. Foundational skills are and always be essential. Even if AI would be crucial, you still need foundational skills to understand why certain AI decisions work or don't work.
responses.graduate_skills_gap: Not sure, we haven't had many interns the past few years
responses.emerging_technology_integration: Blender has overtaken Maya as the industry standard modelling tool. Houdini has become bigger than just a VFX tool.
responses.strategic_curriculum_advice: You would be surprised at how relevant old school game art techniques still are, more now than ever I think. Games are bigger and prettier than ever, but almost always rely on old school optimization techniques to meet performance requirements. Knowledge on these techniques are becoming more rare with the old gard retiring.
